application.ref: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: Tractable Computational Methods for Finding Nash Equilibria of .=
David Robert Martin Thompson Kevin Leyton-Brown .=
Department of Computer Science University of British Columbia {daveth|kevinlb}@cs.ubc.ca.=
How will bidders behave in a position auction that does not meet the assumptions .=
for which theoretical results are known? .=
Main hurdle: existing algorithms work with normal form; infeasibly large for ad auctions .=
Main message: preliminary, but it works.=
 Generalized First Price vs. Generalized Second Price .=
 Weighted vs. Unweighted:  “Effective Bid”: bid * weight .=
Full-information, one-shot game [Varian, 2007; Edelman, Ostrovsky, Schwarz, 2006 (“EOS”)] .=
CTR across CTR across Bid Weights positions bidders Value per Click Amounts .=

Our model Arbitrary Arbitrary Arbitrary Arbitrary Discrete.=
 Action Graphs:  Each node represents an action.  Arcs indicate payoff dependencies. .=
 Action Graphs:  Each node represents an action.  Arcs indicate payoff dependencies.  “Function Nodes” increase sparsity. .=
 Small: Compact representation of a one-shot, full-information game  Frequently polynomial in n .=
 Fast: Dynamic programing can compute expected utility in ~O(ani+1) [Jiang & Leyton-Brown, 2006]  Plug into existing equilibrium solvers (e.g. simplicial .=
subdivision [van der Laan, Talman, and van Der Heyden, 1987] or GNM [Govindan, Wilson, 2003]) for exponential speedup.=

 Validate by comparing with Varian's analytical results for weighted, pay-per-click GSP  and obtain computational results on a model of .=

 Most appropriate model is still an open question.=

Uniform[0,1] Proportional One value Problem Uniform[0,1] * CTR of to Weight per bidder: Discrete .=
 For pay-per-click, normalize value/click:  Scale maxi valuei to 10, then scale other values .=
proportionately  to use full range of discrete bid amounts .=
Size Experiments: Players Integer bids: 0 to 10 .=
 Environment:  Intel Xeon 3.2GHz, 2MB cache, 2GB RAM  Suse Linux 10.1 .=
 Solver software:  Gambit [McKelvey, McLennan, Turocy, 2007] implementation .=
of simplicial subdivision “simpdiv” [van der Laan, Talman, and van Der Heyden, 1987], AGG-specific dynamic programming inner loop1 [Jiang & Leyton-Brown, 2006] .=
[Varian]: Any SNE gives rise to an efficient allocation .=
[Varian]: VCG revenue is a lower bound on SNE revenue .=

 Each agent can have many best responses to an
.=
equilibrium strategy profile.  Raising i's bid increases (i-1)'s price, decreasing i's envy. .=

 Given an envy-free NE / SNE, lowering an agent’s bid
.=
may lead to an efficient, pure NE w/ sub-VCG revenue .=
Not Equilibrium Nash Equilibrium Envy-free NashEquilibrium Not Equilibrium .=

 Even if pure NE exist for continuous bids, they may
.=
Equilibrium selection  Previous results simply showed the first .=
equilibrium found by simpdiv  Often a mixed strategy over arbitrary points on .=
 Local search approach to equilibrium selection:  Start point: Nash equilibrium found by simpdiv  Neighbours: Nash equilibria where one bid is .=
changed by one increment  Objective: maximize/minimize sum of bids  Algorithm: Greedily raise bids (choose bidder by .=
 Many position auctions are tractable:  Polynomial-size AGG  Polynomial-time expected utility by dynamic .=
 Very general preference model:  Position-specific valuations  Non-separable CTRs (and arbitrary weights) .=
 Experimental results consistent with existing theory and practice..=
 Economic:  Use full preference model (learn from data)  Model richer preferences (e.g. cascading CTR .=
 Computational:  In progress: Adapt SEM [Porter, Nudelman, Shoham, 2006] to .=
AGGs: Allows enumerating equilibria (answer questions like “what percentage of pure equilibria are envy free?”) .=
